author: William Baldwin
title: Best ETFs: Inflation-protected Bonds
text:
You can protect yourself from a run-up in the Consumer Price Index by owning a fund that holds TIPS, which are U.S. Treasury bonds with an inflation kicker.This is not entirely a recipe for a worry-free retirement. One problem is that TIPS pay miserably small coupons. Another is that those tiny yields are chewed up by fund overhead. The third is that TIPs with maturities beyond five years can crash in price when interest rates shoot up.The funds at the top of this ranking are reasonably cheap, as bond funds go: Schwab U.S. TIPS ( SCHP ), iShares 0-5 Year TIPS Bond ( STIP ), and Vanguard Short-Term Inflation-Protected Securities ( VTIP ).But don’t expect much of a return. And don’t put too much stock in the official yield numbers published by the funds, which follow Securities & Exchange Commission guidelines that give flaky results. Go to the Treasury’s yield curve page to see what TIPSs are yielding. Select the maturity column that corresponds to the average maturity of your fund’s portfolio, and subtract the fund’s expense ratio. You’ll probably get a real return not much above zero.Rules for the Best ETFs scorecard, and links to 13 categories of funds, can be found here .
